title: How to Make Dark Chocolate Dipped Mint Leaves

steps.headline: Melt dark chocolate in a double boiler.
steps.description: Be careful not to get any water into the melted chocolate (or it will seize).

steps.headline: Dip the leaves halfway in the melted chocolate.
steps.description: Leave space between the leaves to prevent them from sticking together. Use tweezers or small tongs to help you hold the leaf by its stem, if wished.

steps.headline: Arrange the dipped leaves on a tray lined with wax paper.
steps.description: Parchment paper can be used instead, if preferred.

steps.headline: Place the covered leaves in the freezer for half an hour.
steps.description: They will set during this time. They can be left in the freezer for up to 5 hours if needed. Don't leave longer or they may get freezer burn and won't taste as good.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Remove from the wax paper (use tweezers to help). Arrange on a lovely, dainty platter for decorative effect. These are wonderful on their own or as a beautiful garnish to any dessert. Serve direct from the freezer; the frozen texture is part of the eating experience.
